raw_text:
Germany nears 1990 jobless level
 
 German unemployment rose for the 11th consecutive month in December - making the year's average jobless total the highest since reunification.
 
 The seasonally adjusted jobless total rose a higher than expected 17,000 to 4.483 million, the Bundesbank said. Allowing for changes in calculating statistics, the average number of people out of work was the highest since 1990 - or a rate of 10.8%. Bad weather and a sluggish economy were blamed for the rise. The increase "was due primarily to the onstart of winter", labour office chief Frank-Juergen Weise said.
 
 Unadjusted, the figures showed unemployment rose 206,900 to 4.64 million - with many sectors such as construction laying off workers amid bad weather. "The three years of stagnation in the German economy came to an end in 2004. But the upturn is still not strong enough" to boost the labour market, Mr Weise added. News of the rise came as government welfare reforms came into force, a move that is expected to see unemployment swell still further in coming months. Under the Hartz IV changes, the previous two tier system of benefits and support for the long term unemployed has been replaced with one flat-rate payout. In turn, that means more people will be classified as looking for work, driving official figures higher.
 
 "Be prepared for a nasty figure for January 2005, about five million unemployed on a non-seasonally adjusted basis," warned HVB Group economist Andreas Rees. But he did add that the numbers should "subside" throughout the year, to remain near 2004's level of 4.4 million jobless. "I don't expect a strong and lasting turnaround until 2006," German Economy minister Wolfgang Clement said. By 2010, however, the Hartz IV reforms should help cut the average jobless rate to between 3% and 5%, he added. Europe's biggest economy has been too weak to create work as it struggles to shake off three years of economic stagnation. In recent months companies such as Adam Opel - the German arm of US carmaker General Motors - and retailer KarstadtQuelle have slashed jobs.
llama3.2:1b: Germany's jobless total rose for 11 consecutive months in December, with a seasonally adjusted rate of 4.483 million. This is the highest average since reunification in 1990. The increase was attributed to bad weather and sluggish economy. Unadjusted figures showed an unemployment rate of 206,900, with sectors like construction laying off workers. Government welfare reforms are expected to see further job losses as people are classified as looking for work. A predicted figure of around 5 million unemployed in January is "nasty" but should subside throughout the year to near pre-reform levels by 2006.
llama3.2:3b: German unemployment rose for 11th consecutive month in December, with seasonally adjusted jobless total reaching 4.483 million, highest since 1990. Bad weather blamed for rise. Welfare reforms expected to increase unemployment further in coming months. Economy minister predicts average jobless rate will fall to 3-5% by 2010.
gemma2:2b: Germany's unemployment rate rose in December to a 10.8% rate, the highest since 1990. The increase was attributed to bad weather and a sluggish economy. Welfare reforms implemented in January are expected to worsen unemployment figures further.  Economists predict that unemployment will peak around five million in January but then subside throughout the year. The government anticipates long-term improvements with unemployment dropping to between 3% and 5% by 2010.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Germany experiences its highest jobless rate since reunification. Unseasonably cold weather, a sluggish economy, bad winter weather, high unemployment (4.6 million), and government welfare reforms are blamed for the rise in unemployment. The seasonally adjusted figure rose 206,900 to 4. 64 million people out of work.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Germany nears 1990 jobless level; unemployment rose for 11th month, increasing total to highest since reunification in 1990; blamed on weather and sluggish economy, with government reforms expected to further increase unemployment.
qwen2.5:3b: German unemployment rose for the 11th consecutive month in December, reaching an average jobless total of 4.483 million, marking the highest since reunification in 1990 (at a rate of 10.8%). The rise was attributed to winter weather and a sluggish economy. Unadjusted figures showed unemployment at 4.64 million, with construction sectors especially affected. Welfare reforms replacing two-tier benefits system are expected to further increase unemployment numbers. Economist Andreas Rees predicted a peak of about 5 million unemployed in January 2005, which might decrease towards the end of the year and remain near 2004 levels. However, German Economy minister Wolfgang Clement did not expect strong and lasting turnaround until 2006, with Hartz IV reforms potentially reducing average jobless rate to between 3% and 5% by 2010. Europe's largest economy has been struggling under three years of economic stagnation, leading companies like Adam Opel and KarstadtQuelle to cut jobs.
opencoder:1.5b:
Germany nears 19,900 jobless level.

Germany unemployment rose for the 11th consecutive month in December making the year's average jobless total the highest since reunification.

Seasonally adjusted figures show unemployment rose a higher than expected 17,000 to 4.483 million, the Bundesbank said. Allowing for changes in calculating statistics, the average number of people out of work was the highest since 19,900 - or a rate of 10.8%.

The increase "was due primarily to the onset of winter", labour office chief Frank-Juergen Weise said.

Unadjusted figures showed unemployment rose 206,900 to 4.64 million with many sectors such as construction laying off workers amid bad weather. The rise was caused by a "sluggish economy" and a lack of employment in the month before.

Giving rise of unemployment swell still further in coming months, Mr Weise added. News of the rise came as government welfare reforms came into force, a move that is expected to see unemployment swing further in the coming months. Under Hartz IV changes, the previous two tier system of benefits and support for the long term unemployed has been replaced with one flat-rate payout. This means more people will be classified as looking for work, driving official figures higher.

Rees warned about a "nasty figure for January 2005," about five million unemployed on a non-seasonally adjusted basis. He also mentioned that the numbers should "subside" throughout the year to remain near 2004's level of 4.4 million jobless. As to the Hartz IV reforms, the average unemployment rate should be between 3% and 5%.

Europe's biggest economy has been too weak to create work as it struggles to shake off three years of economic stagnation. Companies such as Adam Opel - the German arm of US carmaker General Motors and retailer KarstadtQuelle have reduced jobs.
smollm:1.7b:
The summary is concise, preserving key ideas and details while omitting unnecessary information. The main points are:

1. Germany has reached a 1990-style jobless level in December 2004.
2. The seasonally adjusted jobless total rose by 17,000 to 4.483 million in December 2004.
3. The average number of people out of work was the highest since 1990 - or a rate of 10.8%.
4. Bad weather and a sluggish economy were blamed for the rise.
5. Unadjusted, the figures showed unemployment rose 206,900 to 4.64 million in December 2004.
6. The Hartz IV reforms have led to more people being classified as looking for work, driving official figures higher.
7. Be prepared for a nasty figure for January 2005 about five million unemployed on a non-seasonally adjusted basis.
8. I don't expect a strong and lasting turnaround until 2006.
9. The Hartz IV reforms should help cut the average jobless rate to between 3% and 5%.

The summary captures the main points of the original text, including:

* Germany has reached a 1990-style jobless level in December 2004.
* The seasonally adjusted jobless total rose by 17,000 to 4.483 million in December 2004.
* The average number of people out of work was the highest since 1990 - or a rate of 10.8%.
* Bad weather and a sluggish economy were blamed for the rise.
* Unadjusted, the figures showed unemployment rose 206,900 to 4.64 million in December 2004.
* The Hartz IV reforms have led to more people being classified as looking for work, driving official figures higher.
* Be prepared for a nasty figure for January 2005 about five million unemployed on a non-seasonally adjusted basis.
* I don't expect a strong and lasting turnaround until 2006.
* The Hartz IV reforms should help cut the average jobless rate to between 3% and 5%.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this text about Germany's unemployment situation in 2004-2005. Let me read through it carefully.

First, Germany's unemployment rose for the 11th month in a row, making the year's average jobless total the highest since reunification. That's pretty significant because usually, when you have an 11th consecutive rise, it doesn't go as high as two years ago. So I should note that the figures went from maybe around 4.5 million to over 4.64 million.

Then there was a seasonally adjusted figure where the total rose by a higher than expected 17,000, bringing it up to 4.483 million. This means people were out of work more often since the previous year. The bad weather and a sluggish economy are mentioned as possible reasons. Frank-Juergen Weise from the German Labour Office said the rise was mostly due to winter arriving.

Unadjusted figures show an even higher increase: 206,900 to 4.64 million. Many sectors like construction were laying off workers during bad weather, which is a problem because they might not be able to find work quickly.

There's also a mention of the economy turning from stagnation into a recovery. It says the three years had come to an end in 2004, but the upturn isn't strong enough to boost the labor market. So even though some areas are recovering, others like construction and services might still struggle. The government is implementing welfare reforms through Hartz IV changes, which are flat-rate payouts instead of the previous tier system. This should affect more people, increasing unemployment officially.

A economist from HBV Group warned that January 2005 could see about five million unemployed on a non-seasonally adjusted basis. But over time, the numbers should decrease to near 4.4 million as before. He also said he's not expecting a big turnaround until at least 2006. The economy minister said by 2010, Hartz IV reforms might cut unemployment between 3% and 5%.

Now, putting it all together into a concise summary. I'll include the key points: high unemployment rise, seasonally adjusted figures, bad weather and economy issues, government reforms, and expected trends in January and beyond.

I need to make sure not to explain anything, just present the main ideas from the text.
</think>

Germany saw significant unemployment growth in 2004-2005, rising for the 11th consecutive month and reaching an all-time high. Seasonally adjusted figures showed a higher-than-expected rise of 17,000, moving unemployment from around 4.5 million to 4.483 million. Bad weather and economic stagnation were key factors causing the increase. By 2010, Hartz IV reforms might reduce unemployment between 3% and 5%, while January 2005 could see a rise of five million unemployed on non-seasonally adjusted figures.
tinyllama:1.1b: In December, German employment levels reached an all-time high, with 4.483 million people out of work, making it the highest since reunification. The seasonally adjusted figure was higher than expected and saw the jobless rate climb to its peak of 10.8% in 1990. To tackle the ongoing economic slump, unemployment is set to rise further in January 2005, with a forecasted average level of 2.4 million jobless by the end of next year. The Hartz IV reforms will help bring the rate down to between 3% and 5%, but experts predict that Germany's weak performance will continue as long as it struggles to shake off three years of economic stagnation.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Germany's jobless rate reached a record high in December, while the number of people out of work rose by more than expected. The seasonally adjusted jobless total rose by 17,000 to an average of 4.483 million, according to the Bundesbank. The rise was mainly due to increased layoffs in construction sectors amid bad weather and a slowing economy. German unemployment was now at its highest level since reunification - or the average number of people out of work between the years 1990 and 2004, bad weather and a sluggish economy contributed to the rise. The increase in January is expected to be even higher, with around five million unemployed on a non-seasonally adjusted basis.
phi:2.7b: Germany's unemployment rate rose by more than expected in December, driven by bad weather and a sluggish economy. The jobless total reached its highest level since reunification. News of the rise came as government welfare reforms were implemented, which are expected to cause further increases in unemployment over the next few months. The flat-rate payout under the new system means that more people will be classified as looking for work. While experts predict a slowdown in joblessness towards the end of 2005 and 2010, the average jobless rate remains high at around 10%.
orca-mini:3b: Germany's unemployment rose for the 11th consecutive month in December, making the year's average jobless total the highest since reunification. The seasonally adjusted jobless total rose 17,000 to 4.483 million, and the unadjusted figures showed unemployment rising 206,900 to 4.64 million due to bad weather and a sluggish economy. However, the government welfare reforms came into force in January, driving the unemployment numbers higher and expected to swell further still. The Hartz IV reforms are expected to help cut the average jobless rate to between 3% and 5% by 2010.
hermes3:3b: German unemployment nears 1990 levels, reaching a rate of 10.8% in average due to 11 consecutive monthly rises in jobless numbers. Bad weather and sluggish economy are blamed. Hartz IV reforms lead to expected rise in unemployment figures.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: In December, German unemployment reached its highest level since 1990, with a seasonally adjusted total of 4.483 million people out of work. This was due to bad weather and a sluggish economy. Unadjusted figures showed 206,900 job losses, mainly in the construction sector. The government's new welfare reforms may lead to further increases in unemployment as more people are classified as looking for work. While some experts predict over five million unemployed in January 2005, others believe the numbers will improve by the end of the year. German Economy Minister Wolfgang Clement believes the Hartz IV reforms will help reduce the average jobless rate to between 3% and 5% by 2010.
chatgpt-4o-latest: German unemployment rose for the 11th consecutive month in December, reaching the highest average jobless total since reunification. The seasonally adjusted jobless figure increased by 17,000 to 4.483 million, or 10.8%, due to bad weather and a sluggish economy. Unadjusted figures showed a rise of 206,900 to 4.64 million, with sectors like construction heavily affected. Government welfare reforms under Hartz IV, which consolidate benefits into a flat-rate payout, are expected to push unemployment even higher. Economists predict jobless numbers could reach five million in early 2005 but may stabilize later in the year. A significant recovery is not expected until 2006, though the reforms aim to reduce unemployment to 3%-5% by 2010. Germany's economy remains weak, with major companies like Opel and KarstadtQuelle cutting jobs.
stablelm2:1.6b: German unemployment rose for a consecutive month in December, making the year's average jobless total the highest since reunification. The seasonally adjusted jobless total increased by more than expected to 4 million, with bad weather and a sluggish economy blamed. Unadjusted figures showed an increase of 1 million; if not-seasonally adjusted data shows unemployment at 4 million. Government welfare reforms have led to unemployment rising further in the coming months. Experts warn for a nasty figure in January, around five million unemployed on a non-seasonally adjusted basis. However, they expect numbers to decrease throughout the year and remain near 4.4 million jobless.
granite3.1-dense:2b:
German unemployment increased for the 11th consecutive month in December, reaching an average total since reunification that matches 1990 levels at 10.8%. The seasonally adjusted jobless figure rose by 17,000 to 4.483 million. Bad weather and a sluggish economy are cited as primary causes. The unadjusted figure showed a rise of 206,900 to 4.64 million, with sectors like construction laying off workers due to inclement conditions.

Welfare reforms under Hartz IV, implemented in 2004, are expected to exacerbate unemployment further as more people will be classified as job seekers. Economist Andreas Rees predicts a January 2005 figure of approximately five million unemployed. However, he anticipates the numbers will decrease by year-end, nearing 4.4 million jobless. German Economy Minister Wolfgang Clement expects a turnaround in unemployment to occur only in 2006 and projects an average rate between 3% and 5% by 2010 with Hartz IV reforms.

Germany, Europe's largest economy, has been unable to generate jobs due to three years of stagnation, leading companies like Adam Opel and KarstadtQuelle to cut jobs.
reference: "The three years of stagnation in the German economy came to an end in 2004.The seasonally adjusted jobless total rose a higher than expected 17,000 to 4.483 million, the Bundesbank said.German unemployment rose for the 11th consecutive month in December - making the year's average jobless total the highest since reunification.Europe's biggest economy has been too weak to create work as it struggles to shake off three years of economic stagnation.By 2010, however, the Hartz IV reforms should help cut the average jobless rate to between 3% and 5%, he added."I don't expect a strong and lasting turnaround until 2006," German Economy minister Wolfgang Clement said.Unadjusted, the figures showed unemployment rose 206,900 to 4.64 million - with many sectors such as construction laying off workers amid bad weather.
